title: Quickstart
code: # install.packages("renv") renv::install("N-DucharmeBarth-NOAA/pifsc-odbc")

title: Quickstart
text: using pifsc.odbc, ensure : Oracle Instant Client 23.9+ installed ODBC component Access PIFSC network NOAA VPN Verify Oracle driver available: see Oracle instantclient_23_9 (similar).
code: odbc::odbcListDrivers()

title: Quickstart
text: Store database credentials using system keyring. needs done per machine: ’ll prompted enter Oracle username password.
code: setup_credentials()

what: Download a single table in parallel
title: Quickstart
code: # Automatic year detection and core selection hdr <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR" )

title: Quickstart
code: hdr_recent <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR",   years = 2020:2023,   n_cores = 4 )

title: Quickstart
code: tables <- list(   list(table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC", year_col = "LANDYR"),   list(table = "LLDS_DETAIL_20240315HAC", year_col = "HDR_LANDYR") )  # Download and save to CSV results <- download_tables(tables, output_dir = "logbook-data")  # Or just return data without saving results <- download_tables(tables)

title: Quickstart
text: small tables don’t need parallelization:
code: # Entire table ref <- simple_download(table = "LLDS_SOME_REF_TABLE")  # Specific years hdr <- simple_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR",   years = 2020:2023 )

title: Quickstart
text: need control, can manage connections :
code: con <- create_connection()  # Use standard DBI functions tables <- DBI::dbListTables(con) data <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con, "SELECT * FROM llds.SOME_TABLE WHERE ROWNUM <= 100")  # Always disconnect when done safe_disconnect(con)

title: Quickstart
text: Detailed setup: See vignette("connections") credential management custom connection parameters Advanced downloads: See vignette("downloads") parallel processing strategies performance tuning

title: Database Connections
text: using pifsc.odbc need complete two one-time setup steps: installing Oracle ODBC driver storing database credentials. must also connected PIFSC network NOAA VPN database connections.

title: Database Connections
text: package requires Oracle ODBC driver communicate database. Download install Oracle Instant Client (version 23.9 later) operating system. Make sure include ODBC component installation. installation, verify driver available: see entry named Oracle instantclient_23_9 (similar). driver name differs machine, can pass driver name create_connection() via driver argument.
code: odbc::odbcListDrivers()

title: Database Connections
text: pifsc.odbc uses keyring package securely store Oracle username password operating system’s credential manager. needs done per machine — credentials persist across R sessions. Run following interactive R session: prompted enter username password. stored service names PIFSC_Logbook_user PIFSC_Logbook_pwd default. prefer different service names (e.g., manage credentials multiple databases), can specify setup: need pass service names creating connection:
code: library(pifsc.odbc) setup_credentials() setup_credentials(uid_service = "MY_DB_user", pwd_service = "MY_DB_pwd") con <- create_connection(uid_service = "MY_DB_user", pwd_service = "MY_DB_pwd")

title: Database Connections
text: prerequisites place, connecting logbook database straightforward: returns standard DBI connection object. can use DBI-compatible function:
code: library(pifsc.odbc)  con <- create_connection() # List available tables DBI::dbListTables(con)  # Run a query result <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con, "SELECT * FROM llds.SOME_TABLE WHERE ROWNUM <= 10")

title: Database Connections
text: need connect different database use non-default settings, parameters can overridden:
code: con <- create_connection(   host = "other-db.nmfs.local",   port = 1521,   sid = "other.service.name",   driver = "Oracle in instantclient_21_3",   timeout = 30 )

title: Database Connections
text: Always close connection finished. Use safe_disconnect() error-tolerant cleanup, especially useful scripts parallel workers: use standard DBI approach:
code: safe_disconnect(con) DBI::dbDisconnect(con)

title: Parallel Downloads
text: Large fisheries logbook tables can slow download single connection. pifsc.odbc speeds partitioning tables year downloading chunks parallel across multiple database connections. Make sure completed one-time setup steps described vignette("connections") using download functions.

title: Parallel Downloads
text: Use parallel_download() download one table. function automatically detects available years selects appropriate number cores: can restrict download specific years control number parallel workers:
code: library(pifsc.odbc)  hdr <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR" ) hdr_recent <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR",   years = 2015:2023,   n_cores = 4 )

title: Parallel Downloads
text: small tables environments parallel connections available, use simple_download(): simple_download() opens single connection, downloads data, disconnects. accepts year_col, years, connection_args arguments parallel_download() switching two straightforward.
code: # Download an entire table (no year filtering) ref <- simple_download(table = "LLDS_SOME_REF_TABLE")  # Download specific years hdr_recent <- simple_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR",   years = 2020:2023 )

title: Parallel Downloads
text: download_tables() processes list table definitions sequentially, downloading one parallel. Provide output_dir save results CSVs: return value named list data.table objects, can also work data directly R: omit output_dir, data returned written disk:
code: tables <- list(   list(table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC", year_col = "LANDYR"),   list(table = "LLDS_DETAIL_20240315HAC", year_col = "HDR_LANDYR") )  results <- download_tables(tables, output_dir = "logbook-data") hdr <- results[["LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC"]] detail <- results[["LLDS_DETAIL_20240315HAC"]] results <- download_tables(tables)

title: Parallel Downloads
text: default, parallel_download() download_tables() use optimal_cores() pick number workers. uses 75% available cores, bounded 2 8 avoid overloading database: can override per download n_cores argument.
code: optimal_cores()      # uses default max of 8 optimal_cores(max_cores = 4)  # cap at 4

title: Parallel Downloads
text: use non-default connection settings (e.g., custom keyring service names different driver), pass via connection_args: arguments forwarded create_connection() every worker.
code: results <- download_tables(   tables,   connection_args = list(     uid_service = "MY_DB_user",     pwd_service = "MY_DB_pwd",     driver = "Oracle in instantclient_21_3"   ) )

title: Parallel Downloads
text: parallel download strategy: Open single connection query distinct years available table Split years evenly across workers worker opens database connection, downloads assigned years, disconnects Results combined single data.table approach keeps total number concurrent database connections equal number cores, friendlier database opening one connection per year.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Nicholas Ducharme-Barth. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ducharme-Barth N (2026). pifsc.odbc: Oracle Database Tools PIFSC Fisheries Data. R package version 1.0.0, https://n-ducharmebarth-noaa.github.io/pifsc-odbc/.

what: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: Parallel download tools Oracle databases PIFSC. package provides efficient multi-core data extraction fisheries logbook datasets automatic credential management, year-based partitioning, progress tracking.

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: Secure credential storage using system keyring Parallel downloads automatic year-based partitioning Flexible workflows single tables batch processing Progress tracking performance metrics Optimized large datasets common fisheries research

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: Oracle Instant Client 23.9+ ODBC component installed PIFSC network NOAA VPN connection database access See vignette("connections") detailed setup instructions.

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
code: # install.packages("renv") renv::install("N-DucharmeBarth-NOAA/pifsc-odbc")

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: Store database credentials (needed per machine):
code: library(pifsc.odbc) setup_credentials()

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
code: # Parallel download with automatic year detection hdr <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR" )  # Download specific years hdr_recent <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR",   years = 2015:2023,   n_cores = 4 )

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
code: tables <- list(   list(table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC", year_col = "LANDYR"),   list(table = "LLDS_DETAIL_20240315HAC", year_col = "HDR_LANDYR") )  # Download and save to CSV results <- download_tables(tables, output_dir = "logbook-data")

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: small tables parallel connections aren’t needed:
code: ref <- simple_download(table = "LLDS_SOME_REF_TABLE")

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: Database Connections - Setup connection management Parallel Downloads - Download strategies performance tuning

title: Oracle Database Tools for PIFSC Fisheries Data
text: parallel download strategy: Queries database find available years Splits years evenly across worker cores worker opens connection, downloads assigned years, disconnects Results combined single data.table approach limits concurrent connections number cores, making database-friendly achieving significant speedups large tables.

what: Database Connection Management Functions for establishing and managing Oracle database connections using keyring-based credential storage. — connections
title: Database Connection Management Functions for establishing and managing Oracle database connections using keyring-based credential storage. — connections
text: Database Connection Management Functions establishing managing Oracle database connections using keyring-based credential storage.

what: Create an Oracle database connection — create_connection
title: Create an Oracle database connection — create_connection
text: Establishes connection Oracle database using ODBC, credentials retrieved system keyring.

title: Create an Oracle database connection — create_connection
code: create_connection(   host = "picdb.nmfs.local",   port = 1521,   sid = "pic.pifscproddbsn.pifscprodvcn.oraclevcn.com",   driver = "Oracle in instantclient_23_9",   uid_service = "PIFSC_Logbook_user",   pwd_service = "PIFSC_Logbook_pwd",   timeout = 10 )

title: Create an Oracle database connection — create_connection
text: host Character. Database host. Default: "picdb.nmfs.local". port Integer. Database port. Default: 1521. sid Character. Oracle service name. Default: "pic.pifscproddbsn.pifscprodvcn.oraclevcn.com". driver Character. ODBC driver name. Default: "Oracle instantclient_23_9". uid_service Character. Keyring service name username. Default: "PIFSC_Logbook_user". pwd_service Character. Keyring service name password. Default: "PIFSC_Logbook_pwd". timeout Integer. Connection timeout seconds. Default: 10.

title: Create an Oracle database connection — create_connection
text: odbc connection object.

title: Create an Oracle database connection — create_connection
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ con <- create_connection() DBI::dbListTables(con) DBI::dbDisconnect(con) } # }

what: Download multiple tables in parallel — download_tables
title: Download multiple tables in parallel — download_tables
text: Sequentially processes list table definitions, downloading parallel year. Optionally saves results CSV.

title: Download multiple tables in parallel — download_tables
code: download_tables(   table_info,   schema = "llds",   output_dir = NULL,   n_cores = NULL,   connection_args = list() )

title: Download multiple tables in parallel — download_tables
text: table_info list lists, elements: table Character. Table name. year_col Character. Year column name. schema Character. Schema name. Default: "llds". output_dir Character NULL. Directory save CSVs. NULL (default), data returned saved. n_cores Integer. Number parallel workers. NULL (default), determined optimal_cores(). connection_args List. Additional arguments passed create_connection() worker. Default: list().

title: Download multiple tables in parallel — download_tables
text: named list data.table objects, one per table.

title: Download multiple tables in parallel — download_tables
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ tables <- list(   list(table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC", year_col = "LANDYR"),   list(table = "LLDS_DETAIL_20240315HAC", year_col = "HDR_LANDYR") )  # Download and save to disk results <- download_tables(tables, output_dir = "logbook-data")  # Download without saving results <- download_tables(tables) } # }

title: Parallel Data Download — downloads
text: Functions parallel extraction data Oracle databases, automatic year-based partitioning chunked downloads across multiple cores.

what: Get available years for a table — get_available_years
title: Get available years for a table — get_available_years
text: Queries database table find distinct values year column. Used determine partition parallel downloads.

title: Get available years for a table — get_available_years
code: get_available_years(con, schema = "llds", table, year_col)

title: Get available years for a table — get_available_years
text: con DBI connection object. schema Character. Schema name. Default: "llds". table Character. Table name. year_col Character. Name year column.

title: Get available years for a table — get_available_years
text: Integer vector available years, sorted ascending.

title: Get available years for a table — get_available_years
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ con <- create_connection() years <- get_available_years(con, table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC", year_col = "LANDYR") safe_disconnect(con) } # }

what: Determine optimal number of cores for parallel processing — optimal_cores
title: Determine optimal number of cores for parallel processing — optimal_cores
text: Uses 75% available cores, bounded 2 configurable maximum.

title: Determine optimal number of cores for parallel processing — optimal_cores
code: optimal_cores(max_cores = 8)

title: Determine optimal number of cores for parallel processing — optimal_cores
text: max_cores Integer. Upper bound cores use. Default: 8.

title: Determine optimal number of cores for parallel processing — optimal_cores
text: Integer. Number cores use.

title: Determine optimal number of cores for parallel processing — optimal_cores
code: optimal_cores() #> [1] 3

what: Download a table in parallel by year — parallel_download
title: Download a table in parallel by year — parallel_download
text: Partitions table year column downloads chunks parallel across multiple database connections. worker opens connection, downloads assigned years, disconnects.

title: Download a table in parallel by year — parallel_download
code: parallel_download(   table,   year_col,   schema = "llds",   years = NULL,   n_cores = NULL,   connection_args = list() )

title: Download a table in parallel by year — parallel_download
text: table Character. Table name. year_col Character. Name year column used partitioning. schema Character. Schema name. Default: "llds". years Integer vector. Years download. NULL (default), available years queried automatically. n_cores Integer. Number parallel workers. NULL (default), determined optimal_cores(). connection_args List. Additional arguments passed create_connection() worker. Default: list().

title: Download a table in parallel by year — parallel_download
text: data.table containing downloaded rows.

title: Download a table in parallel by year — parallel_download
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Download with automatic year detection and core selection hdr <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR" )  # Download specific years with custom core count detail <- parallel_download(   table = "LLDS_DETAIL_20240315HAC",   year_col = "HDR_LANDYR",   years = 2010:2023,   n_cores = 4 ) } # }

what: Safely disconnect from a database — safe_disconnect
title: Safely disconnect from a database — safe_disconnect
text: Wrapper around DBI::dbDisconnect() error handling.

title: Safely disconnect from a database — safe_disconnect
code: safe_disconnect(con)

title: Safely disconnect from a database — safe_disconnect
text: con DBI connection object.

title: Safely disconnect from a database — safe_disconnect
text: Invisible TRUE disconnected successfully, FALSE otherwise.

what: Set up database credentials in the system keyring — setup_credentials
title: Set up database credentials in the system keyring — setup_credentials
text: Stores username password Oracle database access using keyring package. Must run interactively (prompts input). needs done per machine.

title: Set up database credentials in the system keyring — setup_credentials
code: setup_credentials(   uid_service = "PIFSC_Logbook_user",   pwd_service = "PIFSC_Logbook_pwd" )

title: Set up database credentials in the system keyring — setup_credentials
text: uid_service Character. Keyring service name username. Default: "PIFSC_Logbook_user". pwd_service Character. Keyring service name password. Default: "PIFSC_Logbook_pwd".

title: Set up database credentials in the system keyring — setup_credentials
text: Invisible NULL. Called side effect storing credentials.

title: Set up database credentials in the system keyring — setup_credentials
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Run once in an interactive R session setup_credentials()  # Or with custom service names setup_credentials(uid_service = "MY_DB_user", pwd_service = "MY_DB_pwd") } # }

what: Download a table using a single connection — simple_download
title: Download a table using a single connection — simple_download
text: Simple single-threaded download table, optionally filtered year. Useful small tables environments parallel connections available.

title: Download a table using a single connection — simple_download
code: simple_download(   table,   year_col = NULL,   schema = "llds",   years = NULL,   connection_args = list() )

title: Download a table using a single connection — simple_download
text: table Character. Table name. year_col Character NULL. Name year column filtering. NULL, entire table downloaded. schema Character. Schema name. Default: "llds". years Integer vector NULL. Years download. NULL (default) year_col provided, years downloaded. year_col years NULL, full table downloaded. connection_args List. Additional arguments passed create_connection(). Default: list().

title: Download a table using a single connection — simple_download
text: data.table containing downloaded rows.

title: Download a table using a single connection — simple_download
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Download an entire small table ref <- simple_download(table = "LLDS_SOME_REF_TABLE")  # Download specific years hdr <- simple_download(   table = "LLDS_HDR_20240315HAC",   year_col = "LANDYR",   years = 2020:2023 ) } # }
